metadata.case_name: Yenumula Mallu Dora v. Petitioning Creditors

facts.text: Appellant Yenumula Mallu Dora adjudged insolvent by Subordinate Judge, Kakinada; receiving order passed on application of two creditors.
First petitioning creditor held decree for money in O.S. 67 of 1949 and another in O.S. 473 of 1948.
Second petitioning creditor held decree in S. 17 of 1955; died during proceedings, respondents include legal representatives.
Insolvency application based on three acts of insolvency and general indebtedness of Rs. two lakhs, unable to pay debts.
First alleged act: evasion of arrest in execution of O.S. 67 of 1949; not accepted by Subordinate Judge, evidence not convincing.
Second alleged act: sale of properties on September 26, 1956 in execution from O.S. 73 of 1952; rejected as mortgage decree.
Third alleged act: sale of properties on September 19, 1956 in execution of money decree in O.S. 9 of 1950; held to satisfy S. 6(e) of Provincial Insolvency Act.
Appellant fraudulently transferring properties in name of wife and brother-in-law; suffered collusive charge decree for maintenance in favour of wife to delay/defeat creditors.
Appeal to District Court, Rajahmundry (C.A. 41 of 1958) dismissed on October 15, 1959.
Revision under S.75 Provincial Insolvency Act to Andhra Pradesh High Court (C.R.P. No. 1725 of 1959) dismissed on March 14, 1963.
Appellant deposited entire decretal amount with poundage and commission within one month of sale; sale set aside on petition under Or. 21 r. 89 CPC before adjudication order.
Appellant admitted indebtedness of Rs. two lakhs; in execution trial admitted no means to pay as properties attached and to be sold, not in position to discharge debts.

legal_issues.text: Whether third act of insolvency under S.6(e) Provincial Insolvency Act established, given deposit of decretal amount and setting aside of sale under Or.21 r.89 CPC.
Whether creditors' petition ought to be dismissed under S.25 Provincial Insolvency Act for sufficient cause due to setting aside of sale.

petitioner_arguments.text: Third act of insolvency not established as entire decretal amount with poundage and commission deposited within one month, sale set aside under Or.21 r.89 CPC; no acts of insolvency remain, petition incompetent or dismissible under S.25.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Or. 21 r. 89 CPC; S.25 Provincial Insolvency Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Sale set aside before adjudication order; sufficient cause under S.25 for dismissal of petition.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant committed act of insolvency under S.6(e) by sale of property on Sept 19,1956 in execution of money decree; petition complies with S.7, S.9(1)(c); appellant indebted Rs. two lakhs, unable to pay.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.6(e), S.7, S.9(1)(c) Provincial Insolvency Act

court_reasoning.text: Third act of insolvency under S.6(e) committed as property sold in execution of money decree on Sept 19,1956; act once committed cannot be purged by subsequent deposit and setting aside of sale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: An act of insolvency once committed cannot be explained or purged by subsequent events; available to all creditors, not erased by paying one.

court_reasoning.text: No sufficient cause under S.25 to dismiss petition; discretion not for ignoring established act of insolvency where debtor heavily indebted, no proof of ability to pay; examples of sufficient cause are malice, collateral purpose, etc., not applicable here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.25 discretion exercisable in very different circumstances, not where act of insolvency established and debtor unable to pay debts.

court_reasoning.text: Object of insolvency law to seize property before squandered; jurisdiction commences on acts of insolvency; appellant in embarrassed circumstances, fraudulent transfers, unable to pay.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioning creditors' application complied with S.6(e), S.7, S.9(1)(c).

holdings.text: Act of insolvency under S.6(e) committed by sale in execution; cannot be purged by subsequent payment to one creditor.
No sufficient cause under S.25 to dismiss petition; adjudication and receiving order justified.

precedents_cited.relevance: Subordinate Judge relied upon to reject submission that act purged by deposit

statutes_cited.name: Provincial Insolvency Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines acts of insolvency, creditor's right to petition, time limit, dismissal grounds, revision

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Setting aside of execution sale by deposit

outcome.summary: Appeal against High Court order upholding adjudication as insolvent dismissed; view of lower courts correct, no interference warranted.

key_quotes.text: An act of insolvency once committed cannot be explained or purged by subsequent events.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on irrevocability of act of insolvency

key_quotes.text: The object of the law of insolvency is to seize the property of an insolvent before he can squander it and to distribute it amongst his creditors.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There can be no sufficient cause if, after an act of insolvency is established, the debtor is unable to pay his debts.
key_quotes.speaker: court
